reviewText: America: Freedom to Fascism a documentary by Aaron RussoI began the night fairly relaxed. I love almost any politically  based documentary good or bad. I have a pretty relaxed affect to most issues in life, and I just tend to never let anything get under my skin (I'm not saying that I'm indifferent or apathetic. I just understand that I can only do so much). However, this documentary has something very different from the others; it reveals the real players behind our government and what their real intentions are.I grew up in the 1980's. My parents were good democrats who votes for Carter and Mondale, and they tried to install their belief system on me. I entered early adulthood as left of center as you can get. I was a Bill Clinton supporter to the bone, and did everything I could to convince everyone around me not to vote for the corporate sell outs known as Republicans. After I watched my choice in President make a mockeryof our country and pass horrible "Free Trade" (which is anything but free) agreements I thought I would give those Republicans another look. Well I voted for George W. Bush in 2000 (Guess I didn't learn from Bill Clinton) just to watch him destroy our budget, fight a fantom enemy called the war on terror, and try to convince me that it was imperative that we invade a country that NEVER attacked us. This of course was for national security. We must invade Iraq so they won't fight us over here?? Of course we won't do anything about our southern border in the process because were so serious about national security??? Something just didn't fit....If the Demacans and Republicrats have lost your trust this is the documentary for you. Mr. Russo will tell you who really runs the country (the federal reserve and private bankers). You will learn all about their grand vision for a world government. Not to mention where your income taxes really go (no they don't go to the goods and services you think they pay for). Learn all about the IRS... Have you ever seen the law that says you have to pay federal income taxes??? Do you know why you've never seen it???The second half of the documentary is probably the most revealing. As one national reviewer stated, "If 10% of this movie is true were in big trouble." Well significantly more than 10% of it is true. There is technology out there to microchip the public. There is a plan to merge Mexico, U.S.A., and Canada with no borders and one currency. The Federal Reserve is not a government agency, and yes they have a lot of power. With every turn this film makes you see how the real players behind the government are stealing your freedom one strand at a time, and in the end their objectives will leave you as their financial and physical slave.Bottom Line: This is a film that could scare the living daylights out of you. But it is also one you must see if you care about the your freedom or the freedom of our children.Proverbs 29:2 "When the righteous rule, the people rejoice; when the wicked rule, the people groan."
summary: Would you like your microchip in your hand or forehead??

reviewText: I watched this video with interest and I gave it a lot of thought afterwards. There are three main things which make me doubt the truth of all that is presented in this documentary.1 - Whether or not there is an income tax law is a greatly debatable point which not even law practicioners can agree on. I am certainly not going to stop paying income tax based on very questionable criteria.2 - I studied more about the Federal Reserve system after watching this movie, and what I learned about it is very, very different than what the film portrays.3 - Many first world countries have I.D. cards and have not gone anywhere near becoming fascist or using embedded microchips to track their citizens' every movement as Russo claims will happen if we accept the implementation of I.D. cards.

reviewText: I just discovered this film and am so glad that that Mr. Russo had the bravery to make it. I'm not sure that I would do the same in his shoes. That there is no legal rationale for paying the income tax is absolutely astounding, and Mr. Russo succeeds in showing that the IRS has no mandate for confiscating our income and jailing those who do not comply with its edicts. Eliminating income tax eliminates the possibility of fascism, decreases the size of the state, decreases government arrogance, and increases the freedom of the people. Not paying income tax is the ultimate libertarian fantasy as it would cause the government to justify individual expenditures for all of their programs which would mean a reduction of the nanny state by 90 percent as they could never justify the great majority of the things they do. It would be the end of their drunken spending and irresponsible theft. They would have to acknowledge that most of their "solutions" do not work, and that there can be no possible explanation for continuing to give them money when we get so little in return. The interviews here are priceless as are the quotations which are so often flashed up on the screen. The message to government should be, "stop flashing our confiscated cash and start showing us the law." Please buy this video and share it with everyone you know if only to laugh at the way the mafia compares so favorably with our sinister government--our presumptive protectors.

reviewText: Although interesting information is contained within the first 30 minutes of AMERICA: FROM FREEDOM TO FASCISM, the latter half falls into chaotic paranoia. It's also noteworthy to point out that director Aaron Russo hasn't directed or produced a film since 1991 (the tremendously bad OFF AND RUNNING). I say this because if someone produces/directs poor fiction, their nonfiction might be questionable also, and this is undeniably the case here.Taking on the American Income Tax code, director Aaron Russo spotlights the lack of legal verbiage surrounding tax collection on the working man's income. That there isn't a legal precedence set up to prove that Income Tax is legitimately collectable is now pretty well known, and Russo's focus on this will likely send goose-bumps up your arms. Why are we paying taxes on working people's money? The simple answer is to help finance the government. And although our government has its flaws (some of them quite large), it is revered and mimicked by many. This still doesn't excuse our government's lack of legal responsibility when it comes to Income Tax collection, but most American's understand the need.Probably the most telling portion of the film was the videotaped audit of one man by the IRS, and when he asks the IRS agent to show him the law that allows him to be audited, the agent simply says that "his badge gives him the right." Hmm. That's pretty disconcerting. Intimidation by the IRS is probably their best strong arm method for collecting taxes (you don't pay, the government sends you to jail, just like Irwin Schiff). That's a pretty strong incentive. Rightly or wrongly, this is why most Americans pay their taxes, and Russo focuses prominently on these questionable tactics. But after this the film starts falling apart.Never does Russo tell or show us what to do about not paying income tax (aside from not doing so and risking jail time and confiscation of everything you own, or voting for political leaders who want to repeal the income tax ...which you'll have a hard time finding, I might add.)From here the documentary sinks even further. Flailing about like a child in a temper-tantrum, Russo then beleaguers us with information on National ID cards and implantable microchips. The story wanders well into conspiracy theory territory rather than sticking to the point of Income Tax collection and our legal rights regarding them.There's also the problem with the fact that documentaries (like fictional films) are a visual medium, and Russo's documentary constantly puts up black-and-white screens filled with reading material for the viewer to laboriously trudge through. What Russo should have done was to find experts on these items and filmed them. But we never see that because ...well ...my assumption is that either there aren't any experts, or those that were felt Russo to be so whacked out they refused to be filmed.At any rate, the beginning of the film is pretty fascinating, but after that you need to be anti-government enough to live in a box while clutching a copy of the U.S. Constitution and The Bill of Rights.
summary: Goes Too Far To Be Credible

reviewText: America: From Freedom to Fascism (2006)directed by Aaron Russoapprox. 1 hour 50 minutesThis movie covers the founding of the Federal Reserve Bank and the negative effects that it has had on our freedom.  This subject has interested me for years and it was great to see people like Texas representative Ron Paul, G. Edward Griffin (author of 'CREATURE OF JEKYLL ISLAND') and Katherine Albrecht (author of 'SPYCHIPS') in a fairly big documentary.  There is no question where Russo himself sits on the subject and he doesn't attempt to do an "neutral" documentary.  While some of the conclusions in this movie seem radical, I don't think that you have to agree with him 100% to enjoy this movie.Russo sets out to find the origin of the Federal Income Tax in the USA or more specifically whether or not we are really legally required to pay the tax.  Of course nobody likes paying takes but most people do anyway.  He breaks down the "if we stopped paying income tax then government couldn't provide anything" argument.  He says before the government ever needs to touch the collected income taxes, the roads are already paid for through gas taxes, public education is paid for through property taxes and defense is paid for by corporate taxes (income tax is used to pay off the national debt).  He interviews people from all over board of the "tax honesty" movement, including the cartoonish Irwin Schiff who is well known for his anti-tax beliefs (one of Schiff's trials is covered here as well). Russo interviews a juror from a different tax protestor trial who believes that the 'not guilty' verdict her jury handed the judge was the most patriotic thing she's ever been a part of.  There are also several former IRS workers in this movie who have gone on to criticize their old employer.  He speaks with various scholars, lawyers and authors who cite court cases they believe point to the illegality of federal income tax.  He covers the "We the People" group who posted an ad offering a large financial reward to those who can "show them the law" that requires Americans to pay income tax.  He attempts to get the "other side of the story" by contacting the IRS which culminates in a circular interview with a former comissioner of that institution.  He also tells the depressing story of how the IRS repeatedly harassed the famous boxer Joe Louis who had given the money from his WWII bouts to the war cause.  They eventually took his $600 inheritance and even took his children's trust funds!One problem I did have with the movie is that it may be difficult to follow for newcomers to the subject.  There are several arguments against a federal income tax.  These arguments are used by seperate but sometimes overlapping groups.  For example, throughout the movie, the mantra is "show me the law where it says I have to pay the federal income tax".  During his interview with Sheldon Cohen, the former I.R.S. commissioner says that the 16th Amendment IS the law.  Earlier in the movie, Russo mentions in passing that this Amendment was not properly ratified by the states.  During this interview however, he uses a totally seperate argument against the tax code, saying that the Supreme Court ruled that no new taxes had been established.  Then he argues that the income tax in reality applies only to corporations.  In theory, all of these arguments can be used on their own, but don't always make sense alongside one another.  What is the point of arguing against the legal "ripple effects" of an amendment that you don't believe is "really" on the books?  The reason this might seem redundant is because different people question the legality of the income tax or IRS for different reasons.  Therefore some strict constitutionalists might argue that the various 'alphabet agencies' (IRS, ATF, CIA, etc) do not have legitimate authority and dismiss them outright.  Others feel these agencies do legally exist but that the breadth of their authority has been extended beyond their own jurisdiction.  The constitutionalists would have no interest in arguing the finer points of the IRS own codes, while the second group sees the lack of clarification of these codes as the reason a group like the IRS has unchecked power.  Of course there are more than just these two positions within the anti-income tax movement.Criticism of the Federal Reserve tends to be more consistent- it is a private corporation where a group of bankers create money and can fluctuate the value of currency at will.  Paper currency used to be redeemable for gold, but over time the connection between the two has been severed and today there is nothing "backing" our fiat money except our belief that it is worth something.  Members of "the Fed" are not elected yet they control our economy.The majority of this movie is spent on the IRS and the Federal Reserve.  When he is done with these topics, Russo moves on to a mishmash of other controversies such as the "Real ID", the implantable Verichip, electronic voting, international trade agreements and finally global government.  While this section will surely be informative to people who aren't acquainted with these issues, parts of it felt a little too ambitious to me and I would've like to see these subjects covered in more detail in a future movie.  Then again, the title screen did say 'AMERICA: FROM FREEDOM TO FASCISM volume 1' so maybe we will see something along these lines.The movie closes with about 10 minutes of text with Vangelis-type music playing in the background.  The text is a plea for people to participate in various forms of activism.It is very easy to criticize this movie from a production standpoint- at times it feels more like a youtube video than a documentary from a Hollywood producer.  The flow of the movie is also somewhat clumsy at times- some sections are narrarated by Russo while others feature onscreen text with no spoken words for several minutes.  Some quotations are read aloud while others are just flashed on the screen, and some sources are cited while others aren't.  The movie can't decide if its a Michael Moore "in the streets" type documentary, or more of a PBS/Ken Burns style presentation of experts articulating themselves.  I sympathize with what Russo is doing but I hope the presenation doesn't turn some people off to the issues covered in the movie.In my opinion, the best movie on the IRS is the obscure 1980s comedy 'HARRY'S WAR' starring Edward Herrmann (younger viewers would know him as Lorelai's father on the hit show 'GILMORE GIRLS').  Unfortunately that movie has never been released on DVD although you can occasionally find VHS used copies.  However Aaron Russo's movie is definitely the best movie to come out in recent years on the problems with our money system and hopefully some of the publicity this movie has generated will lead to more awareness.Anyone interested in the economics behind these subjects should read Murray Rothbard's 'CASE AGAINST THE FED'.

reviewText: "America-Freedom to Fascism" is a superb and surprisingly down to earth documentary that is not just another example of a "black helicopter" government conspiracy paranoia screed.  It is filled with cold hard facts that ones will find impossible to refute and also contains some solid, bonafide history on the Federal Reserve System and the Income Tax, which can be found nowhere in the law books stating that Americans must pay it.  Also, the information regarding the National ID Card is valid and if people think that the Globalists and their plan of a One-World Government is in the realms of science fiction, then they need to do some serious research.  And what better way to do this than to start by viewing down to earth information such as presented in this DVD?  Please, don't listen to the one-star reviewers or even the five-star reviewers on this one, and above all, don't even take my word for it.  Watch the DVD and judge for yourself.

reviewText: Aaron Russo has produced many successful films but very likely his most passionate motives lie in his political viewpoints.  Russo is a Libertarian with a capital L.  He ran for president in 2004 and lost in the primary to Michael Badnarick.  Of course, any third party candidate has his hands full with the Democrat and Republican voters.  I could probably talk about what it means to be a libertarian for a million lines and how my state doesn't recognize the party anymore.  I will say that if you're compelled by some of Russo's insights then I highly recommend you continue to research the fundamental principals of libertarianism as a political philosophy.  With that said, Russo is extreme in some respects but I will attempt to go forth reviewing this film with an oversight of this information and that America:  From Freedom to Fascism does present to us the facts as they are viewed by Russo.  Many will contend some of his key points and others will criticize his presentation.  It is propaganda but then again everything in this genre is.  Don't let the banter and acid tongues out there intimidate you.  Just sit back, take it all in and go along for the ride.Russo presents his case that Americans have seen a gradual erosion of our civil liberties since the early part of the 20th century.  In various interviews he paints his picture clear that we are leading toward an inevitable police state.  I'm not going to get into the nuts and bolts of his arguments, suffice to say it's provoking and opinionated, but not without merit.  Like many documentarians, politics is Russo's engine and the film is his train.  We are the passengers and by the end of the trip we are left to ponder all the facts and challenge ourselves to believe, dissent, or abstain...and we may even ignore but I definitely don't recommend it.  This is the format for all documentaries of this ilk from all political sides.  I have to say, it was nice to see something other than Republican or Democrat propaganda and instead hear the little Libertarian party view for once.  But it is kind of a shame that Russo is not as articulate or as humorous as many.  It was also sad to see this worthy standpoint once again placed on a shoestring budget, much like the party's political campaigns.  Nevertheless, Russo provokes, and his passion alone will demand the attention of most viewers.Russo has endorsed Republican Congressman Ron Paul for president.  Ron Paul is the guy who questioned America's accountability in the 9/11 attacks at a recent debate and Rudy Guiliani responded vehemently.  Paul did not assert that our government was involved but that our policies have contributed to the thinking that justified such a gruesome attack.  Fox News presented this as if he was a 9/11 "truther", you know, like Rosie O'Donnell or Charlie Sheen.  Few have reason to read into the story beyond Fox's presentation, so the perception stands to some degree in many folks' eyes.  It's disgusting but that is what we are up against as a strict two-party system and a society with simple sound-bite driven mainstream political perspectives.  Few even know what third parties are much less actually consider voting for them.  It's a rare treat to see a documentary that gives another perspective some attention, no matter how obscure the film may be.Some recommended reading to supplement your experience with this film or your experience in understanding the American Libertarian party's ethos:  The Constitution of the United States (someone very helpfully specified Section 10 in an post on another review), A Monetary History of the United States 1867-1960, The Real ID Act of 2005, A History of Money and Banking in the United States: The Colonial Era to World War II, Human Action: A Treatise on Economics, What It Means to Be a Libertarian, and The Creature from Jekyll Island: A Second Look at the Federal Reserve.

reviewText: In 1913, it wasn't a very good year for Americans in a financial sense.  First, the 16th amendment (income tax amendment) was created but not ratified by a majority of states.  In effect, this is illegal and tells us we must pay income tax.  Secondly, later in the year, U.S. senators were bribed to pass the Federal Reserve Act without a constitutional amendment.  That leaves us with a group of private bankers (there is nothing Federal or government controlled about the Federal Reserve) who own this giant, private bank and they have supreme power over making money, controlling inflation, and wrecking the semblance of a strong currency in this country.  As far as paper money is concerned, it is basically worthless in today's day and age.`American: Freedom to Fascism' attempts to find out, among other things, the law that says we must pay taxes.  After interviewing many former IRS employees and other experts, it was found out that NO LAW exists that says we have to pay taxes on our labor wages.  There have even been Supreme Court rulings that state it is illegal for the government to tax citizen's wages.  Attempts are made to question the IRS about such matters and their outright refusal of cooperation in any way just lends more credence to the illegality of the whole affair.  In one segment of this documentary that I found quite revealing, an interview is conducted with a former IRS commissioner about the law requiring us to pay taxes.  In the short time he was questioned, this individual's statements were shown to be inconsistent, contradictory and even showed outright deception along with a threat to the interviewer.Suppose we voluntarily choose not to pay income tax?  What then?  That's when the IRS chooses to use such tactics as intimidation and fear, fraud, humiliation, and whatever else is necessary to coerce citizens into giving up their hard earned money.  And after all this has happened, do you know where that money goes?  This program reveals that after interest payments are made and government waste has occurred, NO MONEY collected from income taxes goes toward any government services that American citizens expect, need, want, and deserve.In the latter half of this documentary, details are examined that point to a disturbing trend toward America becoming a police state or something close to that.  Several presidential executive orders are shown that give unreasonable amounts of power to the government and decrease protection for citizens.  Next, it looks at the technology of implanting microchips in the human body and in thousands of common items found everywhere.  And summing it up, how about a national identification card that is due to become a reality in May of 2008?  It all paints a bleak and scary picture of America gone out of control in so many ways.It is quite evident that Aaron Russo did his homework when producing this documentary.  There is substantial evidence and information to back up his findings in the program.  The scope of the material is far ranging and very important although it isn't presented in an orderly pattern.  That was the reason for a 4 star review.  I highly recommend `America: Freedom to Fascism' to everyone.  This concerns our whole country in such a huge way and in the end, it's going to be the voice and power of the people that is needed to make the changes that will get our rights and freedoms back.
summary: Is the United States becoming a prototype for a New World Order?
Title: N/A

reviewText: It was hard to get through the first twenty minutes or so of this documentary because it just seemed to be the same thing over and over: there no law that says you have to pay income taxes...there's no law that says you have to pay income taxes, over and over and over.Combined with the very brief historical overview of the creation of the Federal Reserve Bank -- I would have liked a little more historical detail in that part -- and I started thinking that this was going to be the most torturous hack-job documentary I'd ever seen.However, things start to pick up about a half-hour into it.  We get to see a lot of people who have issues with the legality of having to pay income tax, and we find out that they're not a bunch of cranks and whack-jobs after all.  Some seem very articulate and intelligent.  Also, we get some detailed insight into certain court cases where individuals went up agains the IRS over the legality of income tax.  I found these segments rather interesting.But then, we couldn't just end with that.  We get into the patriot act and some of the legislation passsed after 9/11 and soon there's a multitude of quote-bytes outside their original context hitting the screen one after the other.  Here's the heavy anti-Bush propaganda.Then I thought to myself "All we need now is the Mark of the Beast" and sure enough there came a segment on embedded people-tracking chips and a verse from Revelation on the screen!  Am I clairvoyant or what?So, what started out as a look at the IRS and the Federal Reserve Bank quickly degenerated into a full-scale broadside in my face of every conspiracy theory that libertarian types tend to love to talk about.  Not that there's anything wrong with that, but there wasn't much detail at all.  Each of these conspiracies mentioned at the end would be worthy of a documentary in and of themselves, and I'm sure these have already been done.What I didn't see mentioned among all these fascisms that I'm supposed to be afraid of is Political Correctness, or "Progressive Conformance" as I call it.  When will there be a documentary on something so many have to deal with every day, and that takes away someone's freedom of speech just through peer pressure?  I'm not holding my breath on that one.So, if you enjoy conspiracy theories and you love that paranoid feeling, you'll like love this documentary, and if you are just curious about the "I don't have to pay personal income taxes" movement, you'll learn a little too.  Still, I'm planning to file mine this year.One more thing, the "other side" of the income tax arguement was given lip service, but it could have been more thorough.  I'll bet a Google search on the issue would yield more insights than this documentary's attempts to get the IRS side of things.  I'd at least do a Google search before I'd call up the IRS and start annoying their employees.
summary: Interesting, but I'm still going to pay my taxes.

reviewText: _America:  Freedom to Fascism_ (2006) is a highly disturbing film by libertarian activist Aaron Russo about the decline of America and the loss of liberty by its citizens following what Russo terms a "coup d'etat" by a group of elite bankers.  The film is billed as neither right wing nor left wing, but rather a film for true patriots who are concerned about the erosion of liberties and the increase in state power.  Unfortunately while I agree with the general sentiment of the film, I found it to be disingenuous in several parts.  First, the film seems to assume that America was a "free nation" before 1913 and that it was only after this date that things started to go downhill.  However, while America may have been more "free" for some people at least before 1913, it was still hardly a utopia on earth before this time period.  Nevertheless, I see his point in that before 1913 the state had not nearly grown to such disturbing proportions nor were surveillance technologies commonplace which have enabled the government to further spy on the ordinary citizen. Finally and more disturbingly, the film presents the arguments of tax protestors that the Federal Income Tax is unconstitutional or voluntary.  Whatever one may think of these arguments, the fact is that the courts will enforce the tax.  This means that tangling with the IRS is one of the craziest things you can do and nearly everyone who has done so has had to eventually either back down or been thrown into jail!  The film seems to skim over the fact that many of those presented as "tax experts" such as Irwin Schiff are now serving jail sentences for refusal to pay the tax.  If you want to reform the income tax and want to stay out of jail, you must choose to do so from within.  The film is better once it turns its attention to the Federal Reserve, and the experts presented here such as G. Edward Griffin and Congressman Ron Paul are highly intelligent and come across as very sincere.  Russo quotes Mayer Rothschild, head of perhaps the most powerful banking family on earth, as saying "Give me control of a nation's money supply and I care not who makes its laws."  Russo also shows how the Federal Reserve was created to enslave the American people and how by taking the U.S. off the gold standard enabled the creation of money out of thin air.  Russo also argues that the Federal Reserve is a private corporation and as one commentator puts it "it's about as federal as Federal Exrpress".  Russo also examines the national ID card, whose real prospects are completely Orwellian.  Russo shows how as financial transactions become more and more automated, privacy is diminished and government control and regulation of such transactions becomes possible.  Russo also examines human-implanted RFID tags (or Spychips), alleging that in the future the government may use such chips on human beings to enable them to keep track of ordinary citizens.  Russo also examines Diebold electronic voting machines, showing how the results of elections may be tampered with making the democratic process a complete farce.  Russo also examines globalization, the decline of the middle class as the world becomes divided into two classes of the very rich and powerful and the great masses, and illegal immigration.  Russo argues that NAFTA and CAFTA like the EU are really attempts to eliminate national sovereignity and to create a one world government, New World Order.  Russo quotes from members of such secret organizations as the Council on Foreign Relations about the prospects of America and the manner in which American soldiers are being used by the government to further the schemes of the New World Order.  Russo also examines the role of Big Brother, taser weapons abuse, and government sponsored terrorism.  The implications of all these things are truly horrifying and Russo's examination of America's elites and the future prospects for the ordinary citizen are in line with much of what is currently being said about them.  Russo ends with a call to civil disobedience to reclaim America for freedom and to reclaim our country from the elite conspirators.  The film ends by presenting the case that one should not be a good Democrat nor a good Republican but a good American.  This film is certainly frightening but is recommended to those concerned about the future of the American republic and the kind of restrictions that will be replaced on ordinary citizens.  However, some of what is said must be taken with a grain of salt, particularly as concerns the income tax, because as has been pointed out, messing with the IRS is highly dangerous.  Otherwise the film is recommended to true patriots everywhere.  A final point should be added, that while the film itself is not really of very good quality, I feel that is not so important as the message it presents is highly important and disturbing.

reviewText: This film was not very exciting, but it was educational to say the least. Russo explores the income tax law-or lack thereof-and exposes the IRS and the Federal Reserve as the unconstitutional and illegal entities that they are. I was a bit shocked myself to find out the dubious history and invalidity of the income tax. He also delves into the history of the Federal Reserve and some of their shady practices such as fractional reserve banking, which is essentially no different than counterfeiting. Russo's conclusion is that select bankers have essentially run this country for the past century, that their ultimate goal is world government, and that they are well on their way to achieving it. I'm not sure I agree with all of it, but I'd say he's basically on the right track. Definitely some enlightening food for thought as well as a good scare.

reviewText: Congress is given the Constitutional right to levy taxes under the theory that they are most representative of the majority (a concept known as democracy), so if the IRS were to be dissolved something else would be put in its place.  I'm all for replacing income tax with a tax on exports/imports, sin taxes, excise taxes, luxury taxes, taxes on non-essential goods and services, taxes on dividends and corporate profits, taxes only on income above a certain amount, all similar to what we had before the universal income tax, but that is not mentioned here.This movie and idea is an example of doublespeak propaganda in action - there is no better way to empower fascism than to weaken our democratic government and allow corporations to fill the power vacuum created. For, and this is the fatal flaw in so-called Libertarianism, whether you like it or not there is going to be a government, no matter what the label for the institution that runs things may call itself or be called by others. I would much rather have a democratically elected government running things than private corporations, organizations, institutions, or individuals.The answers to the non-democratic flaws in our government is not to tear bigger holes in our floundering democracy, but to strengthen it instead. The flaws identified in the film are simply pretexts for the tearing down of the entire system in favor of a fascist state (fascism is the merger of state and corporation -Mussolini).What is advocated by the Libertarianism espoused and promoted here is the same thing as advocated by the neocons, such as Grover Norquist: "I want to drown government in the bathtub."  Like all white-collar criminals, the neocons and their philosophical soulmates function best with a greatly weakened capacity for law enforcement.  No matter what the reason is, the effect of destruction of government is the same - someone or something will step in to take its place.Democratic republicanism is the best workable political system yet devised (until we can get the "Sword-in-the-Stone" up and running, i.e.). Perhaps we should try it some time.
summary: Libertarian Lunacy is not the answer

reviewText: In the past few years, I've watched several documentary films critical of the Bush administration, big business and threats to our civil liberties. Some are well done productions, all have an agenda to pass, all contain at least a bit of truth, and almost all are flawed in some regard. Freedom to Fascism was one of the worst of the bunch. I agree with some of the basic assertions...mainly that our income tax system is not fair by any means, and that the Federal Reserve Bank gives too much power to the bankers. In the end, the film touches on attacks on civil liberties...a real concern while Bush is fighting his war on terror.In the end, I thought this was a sloppy film by "award-winning" producer Aaron Russo. I had to put "award winning" in quotes, since Russo makes this claim several times throughout the film. The wiki page has a few Freedom to Fascism criticisms. If I had some more time, I could probably come up with more. Using the Google a couple times throughout the movie, I noticed that Russo was stretching the truth just a bit in order to make his point. Russo has proven himself to be a poor man's Michael Moore.

reviewText: I will be up front about the fact that I stopped watching this DVD after about 30 minutes.I stopped watching it the moment the filmaker began to bemoan the "state of America" and how, once a "bastion of freedom," it is now sliding into fascism.Please.  Which United States are you talking about?  The US State has never been any kind of "bastion of freedom."  US history includes chattel slavery, institutionalized misogyny, brutal repression of labor, jim crow laws, miserable working conditions, and the only successful genocide, along with Spain, carried out against another nation (the native one) since Rome and Carthage.  These are brute facts. Since the filmaker unwittingly gives himself away as dishonest, I don't see a point to watching this. It is an essentially dishonest, NARCISSISTIC piece of tripe.As far as income tax is concerned, sure I'm all for abolishing it. However, the idea that income tax is some sort of conerstone foundation for tyranny is ludicrous.  It is simply the institution of State acting in its own interests, which is that of the elites; it can only be this way and no other so long as States exist.  The aspects of tyranny were always there, you just weren't paying attention - because it just wasn't happening to you. Now I'm not a fan of identity politics, but it is no coincidence that the only appreciative audience for this film is straight white males - taxation is the only way in which they feel politically oppressed. Gain a little empathy.

reviewText: America - Freedom to Fascism is laid out like a crime investigation, with filmmaker Aaron Russo setting out on a mission to find the law that requires normal American citizens working in the private sector to pay an income tax. What he finds is shocking, appalling, and downright depressing: no one in the IRS will discuss the law, or even meet to answer questions, the ex IRS commissioner offers falsities and generalizations as answers (sometimes rewound and played again to allow the audience to fully enjoy the boldness of the lies), and the mainstream media is not picking up the story.This is one of the most well researched documentaries I've ever seen, often repeating important points in different forms to really drive them home. There are plenty of tax experts available to discuss the laws, as well as many ex-IRS officials who resigned upon realizing that their whole organization existed and enforced its code on false premises.One of the most inspirational moments in the film is when Russo is interviewing a juror on a case where a man was found not guilty though he had not filed a tax return in four years. The jurors said it was too obvious that no law existed requiring him to pay one. So, even though he hadn't paid, he was not guilty of a crime since there was no law to break.Towards the end of the film, the scope broadens to incorporate implanted radio frequency chips of the future, the discussion about the "real" id, UPC radio frequency traacking that already exists, and the idea that if the government needs to know every time we make a purchase, go to the hospital, open a business, or receive a loan, then we are not truly free.America - Freedom to Fascism is a very persuasive well-made film. I'd never heard most of the information expressed in this film and checked it out on a whim. If you have a chance to see this movie, don't let it pass you by. This is not just a conspiracy theory documentary, this is a well researched and presented case to the IRS and the federal government asking for proof that we are required to pay a national income tax.If you think that sounds like propaganda, check out the film. I guarantee it will change your mind.
